setup.question: Why did the teenagers in the schoolyard all throw their weapons away at the same time?
answers: The weapons became too cold to touch.
The police were coming and they needed to get the weapons out of their possession.

Text.text: Here's a quote from the detective that explains what happened with the teenagers:

.

There really shouldn't be much else that's left to prove. If you want me to provide context or prove this is about the teenagers in the schoolyard I can do that too.
It is halloween night and two street teenage street gang decided to settle their street conflict in the schoolyard. The kids had
. Judy who was apart of the Scarlet Raiders gang  was enlisted to
. While keeping watch a kid noticed the fight and hollered
She was distracted trying to get the kid to leave when a
appeared. She tried to warn them
But Judy was too late. Last minute the both gangs started
and
. The kids would escape and use halloween as an excuse as to why they were out so late. I have more ev

B: is A lying or giving me things out of context if so let me know, A the same goes for you.

A: your evidence is them throwing their jackets off, but nothing about the weopans. 

Can someone explain to me whats going on in these quotes cause in B's quotes it seems like they're throwing things away cause of the cops which makes sense but then A's quotes come after and they're again pulling their jackets off? how can they pull them off twice someone please clarify
The part of my quote that says "the metal they were carrying" refers to their weapons, their jackets aren't metal... Here's the full quote (go to the quotes tab)
B is leaving out what happens after Judy yells the cops are coming:
(I ran out of quote space but I can provide ev that "they never heard Judy's warning" hence they wouldn't know that the cops are coming")
A. The kids neglect Judy's warning because 1. she was distracted by a kid who ran past her:
run after the kid or stand her post. what

was when the cops came because she knew she needed to warn her gang. She failed to see the cops approaching because of the kid. 2. Yes they were fighting which the narrator characterizes as jumping and dancing:
The gangs were too busy battling to head Judy's already late warnings. Judge A is barely pulling evidence because there is not much to support their answer. I have more EV

B if you have more evidence show it
A can you provide me the evidence between the throwing their weopans away quote and the pulling off their gang jackets quote -> I want to see that whole paragraph 

no one cleared up my initial question -> how can they throw their weapons away twice, why do the weopans turn cold?
Re: your initial question, it "happens" twice because the latter is from when a cop is recounting the scene as per what the kids said:

. Basically the part that B quotes is from when the scene first happens. The part I'm quoting is from when the cops are going over the case and say what the kids mention happened.

These quotes fill in the jacket scene, look at the quotes tab:
The captain of the investigation stated,
the schoolyard wouldn't have anything but
. This shows the the final report when the police were going over the case. Of course the kids wouldn't tell the truth and come up with a lie to evade trouble.

A - how do I know that they didnt just lie to the police 

B - can you tell me why they were fighting, do people in this story have any sort of powers or anything, like what is the science fiction aspect of the story?

If they were really trying to just get the weapons out of their possession, there's no reason they would be "whooping and hollering," the story even explicitly mentions that they didn't hear the police siren or their lookout's warning (B's quote), the story continuously tells us that the cops aren't the reason the kids are getting rid of their weapons.

The sci-fi aspect is heat change, which also happens before in the story: 
First with bank robbers who were in a car when
and in the trunk was

.

Second where a hostage-taker's gun
and he threw it away. The police find, again,
The sci-fi aspect is The Scorpion. But the twist is that he is not real and is used as a scapegoat to drive officers insane. The story refers back to it happening a few years back to officer Wilcox:
But the reality is spreading the notion of cold jackets and The Scorpion branding is

and eventually drive them to the looney bin like Wilcox. Judge there has always been a twist to these stories the twist to this one is that The Scorpion can't be proven and criminals use the tale to evade police scrutiny.
I liked B's logic in this round, A i wish you pushed your logic story more and started with the scorpion. The large text of the cold weopans that wasn't refuted too heavily by B is why I vote A

answers.reason for outcome: B didn't really respond to my evidence

i think I won this debate my doing a little bit of my own logic - if I'm being honest i was far more convinced of B than I was of A until I began to think of th evidence presented. A was a little bit more forth coming however despite all of the evidence that they could have leveraged they didn't. They didn't create a story for me and I wish I didnt have to say that they convinced me however once I figured out my own reasoning i was 95% confident in my decision if that makes sense
I lost because I disclosed the sci-fi aspect waaayyyy to late
